reviewText: This is a very heart-felt tv series about a young boy, Joey and his horse, Fury, and their deep loyalty shared for one another. Episodes are not as sharp as I had hoped, but the stories are still enjoyable and well written. I was really glad to see my favorite villain star, Roy Barcroft turn up in the episode; "Stolen Fury" appearing as an honest (and friendly) storekeeper waiting on Jim (Peter Graves). But, soon after Graves leaves the store, you see the true look of villainy suddenly appear in the face of Barcroft as only Barcroft can do it. Would liked to have seen the actual guest actors credit listings for each of the episodes, even if they had to be listed in the beginning menu episodes prior to the stories.
summary: Fury, A Great Classic TV Horse Series!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I'd love to agree with all the glowing reviews of this DVD set, but in all honesty I just couldn't.Fury was a show I watched every week as a kid. Fury, along with Sky King, My Friend Flicka, the Lone Ranger and other shows of the kind were staples of Saturday morning TV and I was hooked. I've bought a few of those in DVD sets recently and for the most part I've been rather pleased at the result. Unfortunately I did not find that satisfaction in this set of Fury episodes.First, the reproduction isn't very good. There has been no restoration, and the picture quality looks very low-res, with quite a number of film damage artifacts evident. However, the worst part is that to fit these episodes on the number of DVDs they budgeted, these episodes have been time compressed. You can tell from certain jerky behavior in both the picture and the audio. Speaking of the audio, all of the music suffers from a lot of distortion.As to the show itself, as much as I liked it as a kid, it didn't really stand up too well. The acting is pretty stilted and the plots are cookie cutter. Peter Graves' dialogue, especially with Joey, reminds me a bit too much of the cockpit scene in Airplane: "Do you like movies about gladiators?" LOLThe price is right, so for a quick hit of nostalgia you can't get hurt picking this up. Just don't expect to be wowed by it though.

reviewText: "Fury" is more than just a simple story of a special relationship between a boy and his horse. It touches upon themes of redemption in very real ways. Joey is an orphan boy, whose rage at having nobody to love him, almost lands him in juvenile corrections. Fury is a maverick and wild black stallion who no one but Joey eventually can reach. Jim Newton is a heartbroken widower who believes Joey could fill the gaps in his life, depleted by the untimely deaths of his wife and son in a car accident. This program relates through different episodes of a relationship forged by a boy , a horse and a man seeking to recapture purpose in life that is never contrived and upholds the reality of virtue, trust and self sacrifice- qualities which are not emphasized enough in today's society. "Fury" returns baby boomer viewers to a time where wholesomeness dictated programming.
summary: A Home for the Outcast and the Throwaway

reviewText: This is one of those old time shows that deserves to be around for all to see. Some of the transfers are not up to today's standard but what do you expect of a 50 year old show. Highly recommended for any family wanting to spend boob tube time together. Why is this complete series available in Germany but only pieces of it here in America. When can we as American's purchase the complete series right here at home. If you are around 60 years old buy it because you probably watched it as a kid and liked it then, if you never saw and you have kids, buy it to watch with you kids. You and they will love it.

reviewText: I watched this years ago...granted it was in re-runs at the time but it was all that was available early in the morning before school.  The quality is decent given age and the fact that this was originally run in the late '50's.Truly enjoyable trip down memory lane, I don't know that it would appeal to today's generation but for someone that is wanting to bring back memories this does fit the bill.  Campy and written like something from the 50-60's this does not disappoint.  NO special effects, not the clearest filming, and kind of grainy picture but still an enjoyable memory re-lived.

reviewText: I have purchased the other "Fury" titles on Amazon but those other dvd's only had a few episodes on them.  At least this release has 23 episodes--the picture quality and audio are satisfying but not great in my opinion----I do not think that the episodes have been remastered.  My only other beef with this release is the marketing-----why do they call these episodes the "Lost Episodes"?--they are not lost, they have just not been put on dvd before.  And I think all these episodes are from Season 1(1955)---why don't they just say Season 1?  And the front cover of the dvd package bothers me as well.  The picture is of Peter Graves, William Fawcett, and that is not Joey in the picture---that's his friend Packy---why is he on this front cover?  All of my dvd in this package work fine except for disc #2---the "play all" selection did not work--it would return back to the main menu all the time----but you can click on the individual episodes and they work fine.  But I do commend Mill Creek Entertainment for finally releasing a whole season of "Fury", a show that I've been trying to get for years----I even went to one of those bootleg dvd places and ordered the whole set of Fury which I did receive but the episodes had terrible picture quality and the audio was awful as well.  I hope that this company will release the entire series.
Title: N/A
